很久以后，在遥远的银河系：

第一集：幽灵劫匪

一天晚上，在你下班回家的路上，你发现自己面对面遇到了一个神秘的影子。 “要么你的钱，要么你的命。”他咬牙切齿地说。刀尖不舒服地刺入你的夹克，证实了他的威胁。你赶紧交出手机和钱包。你一回到家就取消了信用卡，但他已经在城里花了数百美元了。报案后，你只能希望警方能追上他。

第 2 集：拳头的复仇

几周后，在类似的情况下，你再次被搭讪。 “这是抢劫，”他用略显紧张的语气低声说道。 “把你的钱包给我。”

你停顿一下。 “你的武器呢？”

“嗯……我是一个不杀人的抢劫犯学校的一员。你知道谋杀未遂的刑罚是 9 年吗？我还有未来可以考虑！不行，你要是不肯的话，我就打你。”

他在你看来并不那么强硬。由于对这种莫名其妙的犯罪激增感到沮丧，同时也意识到钱包里的钱，你决定不坐以待毙。你的拳头轰入他的胸口，他的嘴唇发出一声惊讶的“Oomph”。他会用拳头反击，打在你脸上。你用肘击中他的内脏。他摔倒了，你在他俯卧的姿势下又踢了一脚，踉踉跄跄地回到了家。看着镜子里自己的黑眼睛，你还是会因为带着钱包和骄傲逃离而感到一阵兴奋。

第 3 集：新骗局

有一天，你离开杂货店时，街上一位相貌高贵的老绅士向你走来。 “对不起，先生，”他温顺地说。 “你的时间吗？”

“我有一个令人信服的提议给你。你看，我是当地博弈论均衡大学的教授。我的大学最近经历了一些困难，我们可能不得不宣布破产。这就是我来找你的原因。你看上去是个不错的年轻人——而且是个不讲道理的人。我向你请求 100 美元来帮助拯救我们的大学。”

你道歉，然后转身走开——嘟囔着说你真的帮不了他。

“先生，等等！这不仅仅是一个请求，更是一个重要的提议。我知道你关心动物福利：我看到你在“停止工厂化养殖！”项目中投入了一些钱。当你离开杂货店时。我不是一个暴力的人，但我现在向你保证：如果你拒绝我的提议，我将向我所知道的最可怕的农场捐出 1000 美元。”

你停了下来，惊呆了。

“您可能认为我卑鄙，先生，也许确实如此；但我们的大学正处于水深火热之中。此外，你应该清楚地接受——对于你所憎恶的事业，与一千美元相比，一百美元算什么？”

你想了一下。 “我不能否认你的论点的力量。但我为什么要相信你的话呢？也许如果我拒绝，你会用这笔钱来支持大学，而不是浪费在工厂化农场上。”

“啊，这是一个合理的担忧，正如我对像你这样聪明的年轻人的期望。但你的担心是毫无根据的——因为我是著名的道义论教授弗兰克·坎多尔（Frank Candor）， 《束缚之词》（The Words that Bind）一书的作者。如果我不遵守这样的承诺，我的名声就会毁了！一千块钱根本不值得。”

“所以你看，这非常简单。考虑到你对动物的尊重，唯一合乎逻辑的选择就是付钱。”

你极其不情愿地交出了现金，决定避开更多的路人。当你离开时，你看到教授与另一名受害者搭话——一名妇女向“终结世界饥饿”捐款箱投了一些钱。你感到更加懊恼，然后回家，希望有更好的办法。

第4集：受害者的反击

第二天，你避开那条街。但在你下班回家的路上，你发现坎多博士潜伏在一条小巷里。他也看到了你，然后向前冲刺。 “对不起，年轻人！打扰一下！”

你飞奔向自己的街区，拼命想避免收到他的“邀请”。你敲打着楼梯来到你的公寓，疯狂地将钥匙插进锁，打开门，然后开始关门——这时他的手臂伸进了你的大厅。你试图把他推到外面并关上门，但他用力一拉，当你的门完全打开时，你的身体被推回走廊。他靠着门框气喘吁吁地站着。

“那么……年轻人……你知道比分了。一……一百美元……或一千美元……给工厂化农场。你怎么说？”

你瞪着他。 “我以为我们已经完成了。现在你知道我住在哪里了，有什么能阻止你每天回来，直到我身无分文呢？”

“嗯……其实没什么……但我不想吓跑你。”

你坐下来，闭上眼睛，揉搓太阳穴。 “其实，我也有一个想法。”

“你威胁我只是因为你希望我屈服于你的威胁。这已经够糟糕了，我不想让你这么做。但你也不想——那只是你口袋里的钱。所以这就是我们要做的。”

“从现在开始，我将随机化我的回答。既然你的要求比你威胁我的要少十倍，那么我就付给你十一次中的十一次。但十分之一，我会拒绝。这意味着你每得到 100 美元就会损失 1000 美元——这并不比你从不威胁我更好。”

教授抗议。 “但是这个计划伤害了你！近 10% 的情况下，我将不得不兑现我的威胁，从而使你（和我）的损失比以前少 1,000 美元。这意味着遵循这一策略将使您在每次报价中损失近 100 美元的预期。”

“当然可以，但这是一个对称的成本——因为这比我只付给你的费用要少 100 美元，这应该会阻止你提出报价。我付得起钱，因为这是让你摆脱我的困扰的最便宜的方式。而如果我每次都拒绝付款，那么你就必须至少兑现你的威胁一次 - 这会让我们双方损失 1,000 美元。”

你补充道：“等一下。为了确保您不会因为这个优惠而赌博，我实际上会每十次拒绝付款一次。这样一来，每次重试时，预计平均会损失 10 美元。”

“现在我们来掷骰子吧！ 10号，我们都输了。”从您收集的大量棋盘游戏中取出一个骰子，掷出 6。“看来今天是我们的幸运日！我这里有你的钱。”你一边说，一边从钱包里掏出一张钞票递给坎多。尽管如此，他似乎还是很沮丧，并打算离开。

你心满意足——至少在你的处境中能得到这样的满足——厚颜无耻地向教授挥手告别，然后安顿下来过夜。他没有回来。

结论——最后一次抢劫

前两个例子说明了威胁的基本博弈论。第一个故事，武装抢劫犯，是唯一一个他能够可靠地勒索我们的故事。他的刀代表了一方的不对称成本。因为如果我们拒绝屈服于他的威胁并被刺伤（而他不会），我们会损失很多（而他不会），抢劫犯和受害者通过放弃我们的钱包来“妥协”——对我们来说成本很小，对抢劫犯来说好处很小。

在第二个故事中，我们看到这种不对称性有多么重要。自利的主体会理性地抵制强制，即使自己付出一定的代价，因为这意味着其他主体有动力不去威胁他们。因此，进化在人类身上实现了这种逻辑的一个黑客版本，而那些从未思考过博弈论的人经常发现自己憎恨他们的敌人并密谋为他们的错误报仇，即使这意味着代价高昂的战斗而不是不平等的和平（参见许多人）战时的例子，包括乌克兰对俄罗斯的抵抗）。这就是为什么我们第二次与抢劫犯战斗——从自私的角度来看，给他一些钱可能比打架但可能仍然输钱更好，除非我们有抵制胁迫的内在动机。

最后两个故事类似于非因果贸易，特别是非因果威胁。由于没有成本不对称的优势，坎多教授最初能够通过威胁要花钱买我们不喜欢的东西来敲诈我们。但即使他有更多的钱可以花，教授也必须用自己的钱来执行任何威胁，这最终导致了他的毁灭。其非因果版本是某种行为者，由于拒绝向人类提供资源而以负面后果（例如折磨我们的模拟副本）来威胁人类，但必须花费自己宝贵的资源来做到这一点。

我们的随机反应是将支付矩阵从坦率的威胁转移到对他和我们来说更负面的空间的一种方式，这样他就承担了负和相互作用的一些成本。这是有效的，因为我们的情况是对称的。从根本上来说，勒索我们是很困难的，因为我们可以使用我们的资源，即使它们更加有限，就像他在我们身上使用他的资源一样。我们可以花钱损害他的价值观（例如，支持关闭他的大学），或者通过拒绝他的威胁并向我们喜欢的慈善事业捐赠更多的钱来抵消他对我们自己价值观造成的损害。到那时，双方都会因为花费自己的资源和对方的努力而变得更糟。

稍后我可能会写出该论点的更严格版本，但现在我只想指出一些一般性的想法：标准威胁和非因果威胁。

这就是我的想法。

我认为，拥有大量优秀潜在伴侣的人的主要瓶颈通常不是他们的性格或个性。这肯定可以改进，但这不是主要障碍。

我认为主要问题是糟糕的匹配过程。通过朋友见面，或者在酒吧/俱乐部/餐厅与某人聊天，或者根据自己的兴趣爱好聊天，效率很低。一般人一个月内会遇到多少个新的潜在合作伙伴？ 10？ 50？ 100？大多数人甚至不敢与陌生人交谈。

我们生活在拥有数百万人口的城市中……有多少机会错过了建立美好关系的机会？

那么问题来了：训练人工智能来匹配人类有多难？目前该地区有什么事情发生吗？如果不是，主要障碍是什么？如果我们设法训练它以一定的常识 (GPT4) 做出反应，即使它在匹配方面的准确度只有人类 50%，考虑到潜在候选人的个人资料，它也会比 Tinder 成功得多。

注意：我假设人工智能将获得有关候选人的大量信息：可能需要填写一份很长的调查问卷，对人工智能本身进行采访，访问社交媒体、图片和视频等。

更新：在写这篇文章时，我开始意识到类似这样的事情需要巨大的处理能力，而且我们还没有完全做到这一点，但可以制作一个更简单的版本。你只需回答不同的问题，比如你在寻找什么、你想在生活中做什么等等。当然，这取决于信任，但不正确的个人资料可能会被标记和删除。

尽管如此，我认为几年后人工智能将在技术方面出现，能够进行采访并衡量一个人的个性和特征。

话又说回来，大家觉得怎么样？训练人工智能与人类匹配有多难？目前该地区有什么事情发生吗？如果不是，主要障碍是什么？



讨论; https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/s6iNieXDy2HykPMpS/dating-in-2023-sucks-why-isn-t-ai-helping s6iNieXDy2HykPMpSAndreas Chrysopoulos Mon, 16 Oct 2023 18:15:51 GMT Knowledge Base 4: General applicationsPublished on October 16, 2023 12:26 PM GMT

本文介绍了通用知识库的一些可能的应用，这些应用可以使用知识库 2：构建的结构和方法中描述的信息管理方法来构建。知识库的应用仅限于市场上可用的产品，已在知识库 3：购物顾问和有关产品的知识库的其他用途中介绍。

与产品知识库类似，我们可以构建以下主题的知识库：

  • 有关商店的信息 – 例如营业时间、可用产品
    借助这些信息，系统将能够回答以下问题：我在附近哪里可以购买适合我的汽车的挡风玻璃雨刷器？ （排除对我来说不是最佳的报价，并根据我的个人资料中指定的标准，如果有多个此类解决方案，则显示最佳解决方案的最重要细节）
  • 有关服务的信息：酒店、餐馆、修理工、出租车、短期出租房间
    任务示例：我想租一间符合我的个人资料中设定的标准的单间几天，或者我想乘坐公共汽车、出租车、自行车或拼车去某个地方（使用我的个人资料中设定的标准来提议适当的运输）
  • 有关个人的信息：他们是谁、他们能做什么、他们拥有什么、他们想要什么……
    任务示例：找到我附近愿意开始慢跑的人，或者找到我附近能够解决我车内闪光灯问题的人（显示预计维修时间，按价格对报价进行排序）
  • 有关事物的信息
    示例任务：检查是否有人已经报告了十字路口交通灯故障。如果没有，请报告；如果有，预计什么时候修复？

该数据库还可以包含用户使用第一、第二和第三类信息定义的许多其他对象/项目/术语的信息（参见知识库2：结构和构建方法后的图3）。

知识库还可以存储可变数据，例如公共汽车、出租车和私家车（拼车）的 GPS 位置。通常，所有先前的信息值都将存储在知识库中，但出于性能原因需要时可以将其禁用。

知识库用户应该能够订阅对象/项目/术语的属性。如果对象的订阅属性设置为某个值，用户将收到通知。多亏了这一点，他可以例如：

  • 找出媒体描述的故事的结局，
  • 指示系统在书籍出版时自动购买和交付书籍。


讨论; https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/8e9HsZsw8QuRwnqLX/knowledge-base-4-general-applications 8e9HsZsw8QuRwnqLXiwis Mon, 16 Oct 2023 12:26:42 GMT UNGA General Debate speeches on AIPublished on October 16, 2023 6:36 AM GMT

在 9 月 19 日至 26 日举行的联合国大会 2023 年一般性辩论上，许多领导人谈到了人工智能，其中一些领导人特别谈到了存在风险以及应对措施。人们的态度多种多样，从主张采取严肃的全球行动（以色列、英国）到完全不屑一顾（马耳他）。以下是这些演讲中涉及人工智能的部分文字记录，按时间顺序排列。一些特别相关的部分我加粗了。

这些演讲有助于大致了解各国在这一问题上的立场，并表明世界各国政府对认真对待人工智能风险的强烈支持。

第一天

联合国

联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯致辞（链接）

我们还必须正视新技术对人权构成的迫在眉睫的威胁。生成式人工智能前景广阔，但它也可能带领我们越过卢比孔河，陷入超出我们控制范围的危险。

当我在 2017 年的大会演讲中提到人工智能时，只有另外两位领导人提到过这个词。现在，人工智能已成为每个人的话题——一个既令人敬畏又令人恐惧的话题。甚至一些开发生成式人工智能的人也呼吁加强监管。

但数字技术的许多危险尚未迫在眉睫。他们在这里。数字鸿沟正在加剧不平等。社交媒体平台上的仇恨言论、虚假信息和阴谋论被人工智能传播和放大，破坏民主并助长现实生活中的暴力和冲突。在线监控和数据收集正在导致大规模侵犯人权行为。而科技公司和政府还远未找到解决方案。

各位阁下，

我们必须快速行动并修补问题。新技术需要新的创新治理形式——需要构建该技术的专家和监控其滥用情况的专家的意见。我们迫切需要政府、区域组织、私营部门和民间社会之间达成一项全球数字契约，以减轻数字技术的风险，并找到利用其好处造福人类的方法。

一些人呼吁考虑建立一个新的人工智能全球实体，为成员国提供信息和专业知识来源。

有许多不同的模型——受到国际原子能机构、国际民用航空组织或政府间气候变化专门委员会等例子的启发。

联合国随时准备根据会员国的决定主办所需的全球性和包容性讨论。

为了帮助推进对具体治理解决方案的探索，我将在本月任命一个人工智能高级咨询机构，该机构将在今年年底前提供建议。

明年的未来峰会是一个千载难逢的机会，可以根据《联合国宪章》的愿景，在应对这些新威胁方面取得进展。成员国将决定如何推进和平新议程、全球数字契约、国际金融架构改革以及许多其他提案，以应对挑战并为全球治理带来更大的正义和公平。

美国

由乔·拜登总统发表（链接）

人工智能等新兴技术既蕴藏着巨大的潜力，也蕴藏着巨大的危险。我们需要确保它们被用作机会工具，而不是压迫武器。

美国正在与世界各地的领导人一起努力加强规则和政策，确保人工智能技术在向公众发布之前是安全的；确保我们管理这项技术——而不是相反，让它管理我们。

我致力于通过这个机构和其他国际机构，并直接与世界各地的领导人（包括我们的竞争对手）合作，确保我们永远利用人工智能的力量，同时保护我们的公民免受其最严重的风险。

这需要我们所有人。和你们中的许多人一样，我已经在这方面工作了一段时间。我们需要所有人的努力才能把这件事做好。

以色列

本杰明·内塔尼亚胡总理致辞（链接）

女士们先生们，我们的未来是福还是祸也将取决于我们如何应对我们这个时代最重要的发展：人工智能的崛起。

人工智能革命正在以闪电般的速度发展。人类花了几个世纪的时间才接受农业革命。适应工业革命花了几十年的时间。我们可能只有几年的时间来适应人工智能革命。

危险是巨大的，它们就在我们面前。民主的瓦解、思想的操纵、就业机会的减少、犯罪的泛滥以及对促进现代生活的所有系统的黑客攻击。但更令人不安的是，人工智能驱动的战争可能爆发，其规模可能达到难以想象的程度。

这背后也许隐藏着一个更大的威胁，曾经是科幻小说里的东西，即自学成才的机器最终可以控制人类，而不是相反。世界领先国家无论竞争力如何，都必须应对这些危险。我们必须尽快这样做。我们必须共同努力。我们必须确保人工智能乌托邦的承诺不会变成人工智能反乌托邦。

我们有很多收获。想象一下，最终破解遗传密码、将人类寿命延长数十年、并大幅减少老年带来的破坏是多么幸福的一件事。想象一下根据每个人的基因组成量身定制的医疗保健，以及在疾病发生之前很久就预防疾病的预测医学。想象一下机器人帮助照顾老年人。想象一下交通拥堵的终结，地面、地下和空中的自动驾驶车辆将会出现。想象一下个性化教育可以培养每个人一生的全部潜力。

想象一个为所有国家提供无限清洁能源和自然资源的世界。想象一下精准农业和自动化工厂可以生产大量粮食和商品，从而消除饥饿和匮乏。

我知道这听起来像约翰·列侬的歌。但这一切都有可能发生。

想象一下，想象一下我们可以消除稀缺。人类历史上一直回避的东西。这一切都在我们力所能及的范围内。还有一些我们力所能及的事情。借助人工智能，我们可以前所未有地探索天空，并将人类扩展到蓝色星球之外。

无论好坏，人工智能的发展将由少数国家带头，而我国以色列已经跻身其中。正如以色列的科技革命为世界带来了令人惊叹的创新一样，我相信以色列开发的人工智能将再次造福全人类。

我呼吁世界领导人齐心协力，共同推动我们面前的巨大变革。但要以负责任和道德的方式这样做。我们的目标必须是确保人工智能带来更多而不是更少的自由，防止战争而不是引发战争，并确保人们过上更长寿、更健康、更高效、更和平的生活。这是我们力所能及的。

当我们利用人工智能的力量时，让我们永远记住人类直觉和智慧的不可替代的价值。让我们珍惜并保存人类的同理心能力，这是任何机器都无法替代的。

几千年前，摩西向以色列人提出了一个永恒且普遍的选择。看哪，我今天在你们面前说过，祝福和咒诅。愿我们在今天摆在我们面前的咒诅和祝福之间做出明智的选择。让我们利用我们的决心和勇气来阻止伊朗拥有核武器的诅咒，并击退其狂热和侵略。

让我们带来新中东的祝福，将曾经充满冲突和混乱的土地转变为繁荣与和平的领域。愿我们通过结合人类和机器智能的力量来避免人工智能的危险，为我们这个时代和永远的世界开创一个辉煌的未来。谢谢。

目前，许多人最大的恐惧之一是技术。他们经历了二十年前所未有的变革，从基本的手机和短信，到智能手机和人脸识别。人们常常觉得社会已经失去了控制，技术本身在掌管一切，而现在随着生成人工智能的出现，这种情况似乎比以往任何时候都更加真实。不幸的是，我们对未来的看法并没有受到关于机器接管的误导性媒体头条的影响，它们散布了对人工智能取代工作和使人类努力过时的恐惧。让我们明确一点：人工智能将对社会的各个方面产生巨大影响，但我们也必须明确一点，如果我们作为领导者做出正确的决定，这种影响可能会对我们的社会产生积极的影响。再说一次，就像贸易一样，答案不是试图让时光倒流，对不可避免的事情视而不见，并希望它会消失。事实上，答案是为未来做好准备，现在就做出决定，这样我们就可以利用人工智能的力量为公众和未来的利益服务，而不是担心它会成为一场即将到来的灾难。

在马耳他，我们已经这样做了。我们已经看到并体验了人工智能如何增强公共服务，改善所有公民的生活。我们目前有六个试点项目，涵盖从医疗保健到交通管理等领域，通过领导力掌握所有权。我并不是想忽视未来，尽管是的，当然，任何一个国家，尤其是一个小国家，能做的事情都是有限的。为了使人工智能成为全球利益，我们需要采取全球行动。马耳他坚决支持增加和加强人工智能国际合作的努力。技术变化太快，其潜力如此巨大，以至于无法共同合作已经不再是一种选择。

巴巴多斯

如果我们没有相同的事实，我们的民主就无法生存，但我们生活在一个假新闻的产生几乎每天都会发生的世界，人们在这些前提下行事而不考虑新闻是否真实。生成式人工智能将在我们的世界中发挥的作用必须是出于善意而非邪恶，但如果我们要确保这一点，就必须制定适当的监管行动框架。因此，我们支持秘书长的行动，认识到有一天某些人会提出这样的问题：你是否试图维护我们的民主，还是允许它崩溃，以及你是否辜负了我们作为世界公民的期望。我们提出这个问题是因为我们认识到人工智能并不是许多人关注的焦点，因为围绕气候的戏剧性事件和危机正在耗尽世界上所有的氧气。

英国

由副总理奥利弗·道登发表（链接）

但我想关注另一个挑战。这是我们今天已经面临的挑战，而且现在正在改变我们所有的明天。它将改变我们所做的一切——教育、商业、医疗保健、国防——我们的生活方式。它将从根本上改变政府和国家之间的关系。它将从根本上改变这个联合国。

人工智能——世界上已知的最大变革。作为政府，我们的任务是理解它、掌握它并寻求治理它。我们必须尽快做到这一点。想想短短几个月内发生了多少变化。然后想想五年或十年后这个世界将会有何不同。

我们正在快速熟悉今天的人工智能，但我们需要为明天的人工智能做好准备。在这个前沿，我们需要承认我们根本不知道可能性的界限。我们就像电灯亮起之前的爱迪生，或者第一封电子邮件发送之前的蒂姆·伯纳斯·李。他们当然无法分别想象纽约天际线在夜间的照明，或现代互联网的奇迹。但他们怀疑自己的发明具有变革性的力量。

前沿人工智能能够在几秒钟内处理全部人类知识，它不仅有可能改变我们的生活，而且有可能重新构想我们对科学的理解。

如果——像我一样——你相信人类正在解开最小粒子或宇宙最远距离的奥秘，如果你认为千年奖问题最终是可以解决的，或者我们最终将完全理解病毒，那么你肯定会同意，通过以可能令人眼花缭乱的规模增加我们的智力总和，前沿人工智能将在我们有生之年快速解开其中至少一些答案。因为在人工智能时代，年就是天，甚至是小时。 “边界”并不像我们想象的那么远。

现在，这带来了巨大的机遇。今天开发的人工智能模型可以提供应对气候变化所需的能源效率，刺激养活世界所需的农作物产量，检测慢性疾病或流行病的迹象，更好地管理供应链，以便每个人都能获得他们需要的材料和商品，并提高企业和政府的生产力。

事实上，今年大会上讨论的每一个挑战以及更多挑战都可以通过人工智能得到改善甚至解决。

也许最令人兴奋的是人工智能可以成为一种向所有人开放的民主化工具。正如我们看到数字技术席卷整个发展中国家一样，人工智能有潜力为地球各地的数百万人提供支持，让每个人，无论身在何处，都有能力参与这场革命。

人工智能可以而且应该成为所有人的工具。然而，任何可供所有人使用的技术也可能被用来作恶。我们已经看到了人工智能可能带来的危险：青少年窃取个人银行详细信息；恐怖分子瞄准政府系统；网络犯罪分子用深度造假和机器人欺骗选民；甚至是压制其人民的国家。

但我们对风险的关注必须包括代理前沿人工智能的潜力，它立即超越了我们的集体智慧，并且违背了我们的理解。

事实上，许多人认为这项技术与众不同，因为它的创造者自己甚至不知道它是如何工作的。他们无法解释为什么它会这样做，他们无法预测它将做什么或不会做什么。因此，前沿人工智能的主要风险将来自误用、意外事故或与人类目标不一致。我们需要努力预防所有这些可能性，并齐心协力就这些风险达成共识。

这就是英国 11 月主办的人工智能安全峰会将寻求实现的目标。尽管我们在今年早些时候看到一些专家的恳求，但我不相信我们能够阻止这股潮流。未来这项技术不会以惊人的速度发展。尽管我赞赏领先企业将安全置于其发展核心的努力，以及它们为防止不安全部署提供防护的自愿承诺，但全球竞争性竞赛的发令枪已经打响，在这场竞争中，各个公司以及国家都将努力尽可能远、更快地突破界限。

事实上，这些公司的既定目标是建立超级智能：努力以各种可能的方式超越人类智能的人工智能。

现在一些从事这方面工作的人认为几年后就能实现。政府面临的问题是我们如何应对这一问题。速度和规模要求领导者对影响和潜力有清醒的认识。

我们不能陷入关于人工智能是行善工具还是作恶工具的争论；它将成为双方的工具。

我们必须为两者做好准备，并防范后者。

国际社会必须以同样的力度和热情应对机遇和风险。

过去，领导人通过追溯监管来应对科技发展。但在这种情况下，必要的护栏、监管和治理必须与技术进步并行发展。然而，目前全球监管落后于当前的进展。立法者必须吸引所有人——开发商、专家、学者——提前了解可能出现的机遇和风险。我们必须成为与前沿创新者并肩的前沿政府，英国决心成为先锋，通过广岛七国集团进程、人工智能全球伙伴关系和经合组织与联合国志同道合的盟友合作。

我国是一个具有独特地位的国家。我们有前沿科技公司。我们拥有世界领先的大学。我们在生成人工智能方面的投资是最高的。当然，我们拥有工业革命和计算革命的遗产。

这个腹地为我们奠定了人工智能成功和安全的基础。

它们是同一枚硬币的两面，我们的总理已将人工智能安全置于其雄心壮志的首位。

现在，我们认识到，当然，每个国家都希望保护自己的利益和战略优势，但我们将采取的最重要的行动将是国际性的。

事实上，由于科技公司和非国家行为者在人工智能领域往往具有国家规模的影响力和突出地位，因此这一挑战需要一种新形式的多边主义。因为只有通过共同努力，我们才能让人工智能对每个人来说都是安全的。

我们将于 11 月举办的首届人工智能安全峰会将启动这一进程，重点关注前沿技术。我们特别希望关注最严重的可能风险，例如破坏生物安全的可能性，或增加人们进行网络攻击的能力，以及失去对机器本身控制的危险。

对于那些认为这些警告是耸人听闻或属于科幻小说领域的人，我只是指出数百名人工智能开发人员、专家和学者的言论，我引用他们的话：

“与流行病和核战争等其他社会规模的风险一样，减轻人工智能带来的灭绝风险应该成为全球优先事项。 ”

现在，我站在这里并不是自称是人工智能专家，但我确实相信政策制定者和政府忽视这一专家共识将导致我们所有公民面临危险。

我们的峰会旨在就这些最极端的风险以及世界应如何应对这些风险达成共识。与此同时，关注如何安全地将人工智能用于公共利益。

这一进展的速度要求这不是一次性的，甚至不是一年一度的聚会。新的突破每天都在发生，我们需要更定期地召开会议。此外，我们必须将政府与最优秀的学者和研究人员聚集在一起，以便能够评估这些技术。

科技公司不得给自己做作业，就像政府和公民必须相信风险得到适当缓解一样。事实上，这项工作的很大一部分应该是确保人们对体系的信心，只有民族国家才能提供最重要的已缓解的国家安全担忧。

现在，这就是为什么我感到非常自豪，因为英国世界领先的前沿人工智能工作组汇集了 Yoshua Bengio 和 Paul Christiano 等先驱专家，以及 GCHQ 负责人和我们的国家安全顾问。它是世界上第一个正在发展进行安全外部红队能力的此类机构，这对于建立对前沿模型的信心至关重要。我们的目标是使工作组发展成为一个具有国际影响力的永久性机构结构。

在自由民主国家建设这种能力非常重要。许多世界一流的技术都是在言论公开、思想自由交流的国家开发的。规则和透明的文化对于创造力和创新至关重要，对于确保人工智能安全也同样重要。

因此，女士们、先生们，这就是我们面临的任务。

它的速度、规模和潜力与我们或我们的前辈以前所了解的任何事物都不同。

令人兴奋。令人畏惧。势不可挡。

因此，我们必须与它的先驱者一起努力了解它、治理它、利用它的潜力并控制它的风险。我们也必须成为先锋。

我们可能不知道风险在哪里，如何控制风险，甚至不知道我们必须在哪些论坛上确定风险。然而，我们所知道的是，当各国共同努力时，最有力的行动将会到来。

人工智能革命将是对多边体系的一次严峻考验，以表明多边体系可以在有助于确定人类命运的问题上共同努力。

我们的未来——人类的未来——我们整个地球的未来，取决于我们这样做的能力。

这是我们的挑战，也是我们的机遇。

真正成为联合国。

我们已经拥有无需人类手指扣动扳机的自主武器系统。见证我们周围的战争，正如秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯在本周大会开幕式上所说，“生成式人工智能前景广阔，但它也可能引导我们越过卢比孔河，陷入超出我们控制范围的危险”，取消引用，在战争与和平的战场上尤其如此。人工智能将从根本上颠覆我们对军事学说和战略威慑的假设。例如，人工智能支持的武器系统几乎可以在瞬间部署和触发，这将大大减少我们领导人的决策时间，并且在很多情况下，人类甚至可能不在射击循环中，但我们将在火线。这将不可避免地增加意外冲突或冲突升级的风险。冷战期间，“确保相互毁灭”的观念强加了相互克制，尽管我们现在知道事实上有过几次险些发生的情况。核升级的幽灵并未消失。然而，人工智能在冲突局势中的出现实际上成倍增加了风险。

这是一篇介绍我们新论文“强化学习中的古德哈特定律”的博文。我们根据经验研究强化学习中的古德哈特定律，为其发生的原因提供几何解释，并利用这些见解推导出两种可证明避免古德哈廷定律的方法。

这里，我们只包括几何解释（也可以在附录A中找到）和提前停止算法的直观描述。其余内容请参阅链接的论文。

介绍

假设我们想要优化某些结果，但我们只能测量与该结果或多或少相关的不完美代理。一个典型的例子是学校：我们希望孩子们学习材料，但学校只能观察由他们的成绩组成的不完美代理。当学生没有在考试中取得好成绩的压力时，结果可能会很好地反映他们的真实理解水平。 But this changes once we start putting pressure on students to do get good grades. Then, the correlation usually breaks: students learn "for the test", cheat, or use other strategies which make them get better marks without necessarily increasing their true understanding.

That "any observed statistical regularity will tend to collapse once pressure is placed upon it for control purposes" (or " when a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure ") is called the Goodhart's law . Graphically, plotting the true reward and the proxy reward obtained along increasing optimisation pressure, we might therefore expect to see something like the following graph:

In machine learning, this phenomenon has been studied before. We have a long list lot of examples where agents discover surprising ways of getting reward without increasing their true performance. These examples, however, have not necessarily been quantified over increasing optimisation pressure: we only know that agents discovered those "reward hacks" at some point in their training. Even in cases where the effect was attributed specifically to the increasing optimisation pressure, we lacked a true, mechanistic understanding for why it happens.

Our paper fills this gap. The core contribution is an explanation for Goodhart's law in reinforcement learning in terms of the geometry of Markov decision processes. We use this theoretical insight to develop new methods for provably avoiding Goodharting and for optimising reward under uncertainty. We also show empirically that Goodharting occurs quite often in many different MDPs and investigate the performance of our early-stopping method (which, being pessimistic, might usually lose on some reward).

Geometric explanation

Suppose that we work with a fixed MDP, with | S | states, | A | actions (we assume both being finite) and a discount factor γ . We are interested in the space Π of (Markov) policies π : S → Δ ( A ) giving, for every state s , a probability distribution over actions. For every reward R we can compute the expected return J R ( π ) for any policy π . Unfortunately, the function J R : Π → R can be quite complex. However, it turns out that instead of working with policies, we might instead choose to work with state-action occupancy measures . There is an occupancy measure η π for each policy π : it is defined over pairs (state s , action a ), and indicates roughly how often we take action a in state s . Formally:

η π ( s , a ) = ∞ ∑ t = 0 γ t P ( S t = s , A t = a )

but the exact form is not really needed to understand the explanation below.

The state-action occupancy measure space has a number of extremely nice properties:

  • We can recover a policy π from its occupancy measure η π (up to the states that were never visited).
  • The space of occupancy measures Ω is a convex hull over a finite number of points, corresponding to occupancy measures of deterministic policies.
  • Moreover, Ω lies in the affine subspace of dimension| S | ( | A | − 1 ) (we will denote the orthogonal projection matrix to that subspace by M ).
  • If we treat rewards on MDPs as vectors R ∈ R | S | × | A | , then the RL cost function can be decomposed as J R ( π ) = η π ⋅ R . In other words, each reward R induces a linear function on the convex polytope Ω , which reduces finding the optimal policy to solving a linear programming problem in Ω !

In short: the space of policies over a MDP can be understood as a certain polytope Ω , where for a given reward R , finding optimal policy for R is really solving a linear program. Or, putting it differently, the gradient of R is a linear function in the polytope .

We can visualise it as follows:

Here the red arrow denotes the direction of R 1 within Ω . Note that this direction corresponds to M R 1 , rather than R 1 , since Ω lies in a lower-dimensional affine subspace. Similarly, the red lines correspond to the level sets of R 1 , ie the directions we can move in without changing R 1 .

Now, if R 1 is a proxy reward , then we may assume that there is also some (unknown) true reward function R 0 . This reward also induces a linear function on Ω , and the angle between them is θ :

Suppose we pick a random point η π in Ω , and then move in a direction that increases η π ⋅ R 1 . This corresponds to picking a random policy π , and then modifying it in a direction that increasesJ R 1 ( π ) . In particular, let us consider what happens to the true reward function R 0 , as we move in the direction that most rapidly increases the proxy reward R 1 .

To start with, if we are in the interior of Ω (ie, not close to any constraints), then the direction that most rapidly increases R 1 is to move parallel to M R 1 . Moreover, if the angle θ between M R 1 and M R 0 is no more than π / 2 , then this is guaranteed to also increase the value of R 0 . To see this, consider the following diagram:

However, as we move parallel to M R 1 , we will eventually hit the boundary of Ω . When we do this, the direction that most rapidly increases R 1 will no longer be parallel to M R 1 . Instead, it will be parallel to the projection of R 1 onto the boundary of Ω that we just hit. Moreover, if we keep moving in this direction, then we might no longer be increasing the true reward R 0 . To see this, consider the following diagram:

The dashed green line corresponds to the path that most rapidly increases R 1 . As we move along this path, R 0 initially increases. However, after the path hits the boundary of Ω and changes direction, R 0 will instead start to decrease. Thus, if we were to plotJ R 1 ( π ) andJ R 0 ( π ) over time, we would get a plot that looks roughly like this:

Next, it is important to note that R 0 is not guaranteed to decrease after we hit the boundary of Ω . To see this, consider the following diagram:

The dashed green line again corresponds to the path that most rapidly increases R 1 . As we move along this path, R 0 will increase both before and after the path has hit the boundary of Ω . If we were to plotJ R 1 ( π ) andJ R 0 ( π ) over time, we would get a plot that looks roughly like this:

The next thing to note is that we will not just hit the boundary of Ω once. If we pick a random point η π in Ω , and keep moving in the direction that most rapidly increases η π ⋅ R 1 until we have found the maximal value of R 1 in Ω , then we will hit the boundary of Ω over and over again. Each time we hit this boundary we will change the direction that we are moving in, and each time this happens, there is a risk that we will start moving in a direction that decreases R 0 .

Goodharting corresponds to the case where we follow a path through Ω along which R 0 initially increases, but eventually starts to decrease. As we have seen, this must be caused by the boundaries of Ω .

We may now ask; under what conditions do these boundaries force the path of steepest ascent (of R 1 ) to move in a direction that decreases R 0 ? By inspecting the above diagrams, we can see that this depends on the angle between the normal vector of that boundary and M R 1 , and the angle between M R 1 and M R 0 . In particular, in order for R 0 to start decreasing, it has to be the case that the angle between M R 1 and M R 0 is larger than the angle between M R 1 and the normal vector of the boundary of Ω . This immediately tells us that if the angle between M R 1 and M R 0 is small, then Goodharting will be less likely to occur.

Moreover, as the angle between M R 1 and the normal vector of the boundary of Ω becomes smaller , Goodharting should be correspondingly more likely to occur. In our paper, Proposition 3 tells us that this angle will decrease monotonically along the path of steepest ascent (of R 1 ). As such, Goodharting will get more and more likely the further we move along the path of steepest ascent. This explains why Goodharting becomes more likely when more optimisation pressure is applied.

How can we use this intuition?

Preventing Goodharting is difficult because we only have access to the proxy reward. If we only observe R 1 , we don't know whether we are in the situation on the left or the situation on the right:

However, we might detect that there is a danger of Goodharting: if we have a bound on the angle θ between the true and the proxy, then we can detect when there is at least one policy within a cone of θ around R 1 whose return goes down. This is the idea for the pessimistic early stopping algorithm we have developed. Specifically, we track the current direction of optimisation relative to the proxy reward R 1 given by α i + 2 = arg ( η i + 2 − η i + 1 , R 1 ) , in the occupancy measure space:

If α + θ >; π / 2 , or equivalently, cos ( α ) < cos ( π / 2 − θ ) = sin ( θ ) , there is a possibility of Goodharting - since pessimistically, we are moving opposite to some possible true reward R 0 .

In the interior of the polytope Ω , we know that the increase in return is given by the product of how much we moved and the magnitude of the (projected) reward vector : J R 1 ( π i + 1 ) − J R 1 ( π i ) = | | η i + 1 − η i | | ⋅ | | M R 1 | | 。 In general, it has to be rescaled by the current direction of optimisation: J R 1 ( π i + 2 ) − J R 1 ( π i + 1 ) = cos ( α i + 2 ) | | η i + 2 − η i + 1 | | ⋅ | | M R 1 | | 。

Therefore, assuming that the LHS of the following inequality is non-increasing (Proposition 3 in the paper again):

J R 1 ( π i + 1 ) − J R 1 ( π i ) | | η π i + 1 − η π i | | < sin ( θ ) | | M R 1 | |

we can simply stop first i that satisfies it. This is the optimal (last possible) point where we still provably avoid Goodharting.

What's next?

Early-stopping can, unfortunately, lose out on quite a lot of reward, so we think this particular method can be best used in situations where it is much more important to prevent Goodharting than to get good performance in absolute terms. It is also expensive to compute the occupancy measure η and the angle θ . Still, the algorithm can be improved in many directions: for example, we might be able to construct a training algorithm where we alternate between (1) training a model and (2) collecting more data about the reward function. In this way, we collect just enough information for training to proceed, without ever falling into Goodharting. We write about some of those possibilities in the paper but leave the details for future work.

I work in the startup sphere, in field robotics, and I am about to have an opportunity to majorly shift what I am working on. To work out what projects might make sense on a multi-year time frame, I wrote up what I thought might happen in AI in the next couple of years as specifically as I could.

Partly inspired by The Crux List , the following is a non-comprehensive taxonomy of positions which imply that we should not be worried about existential risk from artificial superintelligence.

Each position individually is supposed to be a refutation of AI X-risk concerns as a whole. These are mostly structured as specific points of departure from the regular AI X-risk position, taking the other areas as a given. This may result in skipping over positions which have multiple complex dependencies.

Some positions are given made-up labels, including each of the top-level categories: "Fizzlers", "How-skeptics", "Why-skeptics", "Solvabilists", and "Anthropociders".

(Disclaimer: I am not an expert on the topic. Apologies for any mistakes or major omissions.)

Taxonomy

  1. "Fizzlers": Artificial superintelligence is not happening.
    1. AI surpassing human intelligence is fundamentally impossible (or at least practically impossible).
      1. True intelligence can only be achieved in biological systems, or at least in systems completely different from computers.
        1. Biological intelligences rely on special quantum effects, which computers cannot replicate.
        2. Dualism: The mental and physical are fundamentally distinct, and non-mental physical constructions cannot create mental processes.
        3. Intelligence results from complex, dynamic systems of a kind which cannot be modeled mathematically by computers.
      2. Mysterianists: A particular key element of human thinking, such as creativity, common sense, consciousness, or conceptualization, is so beyond our ability to understand that we will not be able to create an AI that can achieve it. Without this element, superintelligence is impossible.
      3. Intelligence isn't a coherent or meaningful concept. Capability gains do not generalize.
      4. There is a fundamental ceiling on intelligence, and it is around where humans are.
    2. "When-skeptics": ASI is very, very far away .
      1. Moore's Law is stopping, scaling will hit fundamental limits, training data is running out and can't be easily supplemented, algorithmic improvements will level off, and/or other costs will skyrocket as AI gets better.
      2. Existing methods will peak in capabilities, and future development will continue down an entirely different path, greatly delaying progress.
      3. Biological anchors point to ASI taking a very long time.
      4. In general, either in large engineering projects or AI in particular, progress tends to be more difficult than people expect it to be.
    3. Apocalyptists: The end of civilization is imminent, and will happen before AI would takeoff.
      1. A sociopolitical phenomenon will soon cause societal, economic, and/or political collapse.
      2. We're on the cusp of some apocalyptic scientific accident, from "grey goo" nanotech, a collider catastrophe, black ball technology , an engineered pathogen leak, or some other newly researched development.
      3. Environmental harm will soon cause runaway climate change, a global ecological collapse, or some other civilization-ending disaster.
      4. War will soon break out, and we'll die via nuclear holocaust, an uncontrollable bioweapon strike, radiological or chemical weaponry, etc.
      5. Fermi Paradox: If it were possible to achieve ASI before extinction, we would have seen alien AIs.
    4. Outside view:
      1. Most times when people think "the world is about to change tremendously", the world doesn't actually change. People are biased towards arriving at conclusions that include apocalypse. This category of topic is a thing people are often wrong about.
      2. Market indicators signal that near-term ASI is unlikely, assuming the Efficient Market Hypothesis is true.
      3. AI risk is fantastical and "weird", and thus implausible. The concept sounds too much like fiction (it fits as a story setting), it has increased memetic virality, and a "clickbait"-feeling. The people discussing it are often socially identified as belonging to non-credible.
      4. Various people have ulterior motives for establishing AI doom as a possibility, so arguments can't be taken at face value.
        1. Psychological motivations: People invent AI doom because of a psychological need for a pseudo-deity or angelic/demonic figures, or for eschatology, or to increase the felt significance of themselves or technology, or to not have to worry about the long-term future, etc.
        2. Some groups have incentives to make the public believe that doom is likely: Corporates want regulatory capture, hype, investment, or distraction, and think the "our product is so dangerous it will murder you and your family" is a good way to achieve that; alignment researchers want funding and to be taken more seriously; activists want to draw attention towards or away from certain other AI issues.
  2. "How-skeptics": ASI won't be capable of taking over or destroying the world.
    1. Physical outer control is paramount, and cannot be overcome. Control over physical hardware means effective control.
      1. A physical body is necessary for getting power. Being only able to communicate is sufficiently limiting.
      2. It will be possible to coordinate "sandboxing" all AI, ensuring that it can't communicate with the outside world at all, and this will be enough to keep it constrained.
    2. We can and will implement off-buttons in all AI (which the AI will not circumvent), accurately detect when any AI may be turning toward doing anything dangerous, and successfully disable the AI under those circumstances, without any AI successfully interfering with this.
    3. Power and ability don't come from intelligence , in general. The most intelligent humans are not the most powerful.
    4. Human intelligence already covers most of what intelligence can do. The upper bound of theoretically-optimal available strategies for accomplishing things does not go much farther than things already seen, and things we've seen in highest-performance humans are not impressive. Science either maxes out early or cannot be accomplished without access to extensive physical resources. There are no "secret paths" that are not already known, no unknown unknowns that could lead to unprecedented capabilities.
      1. (Various arguments getting into the nitty-gritty of what particular things intelligence can get you: about science ability, nanotech, biotech, persuasiveness, technical/social hacking, etc.)
    5. Artificial intelligence can be overcome by the population and/or diversity of humanity. Even if AI becomes much smarter than any individual human, no amount of duplicates/variants could become smarter than all humanity combined.
    6. Many AIs will be developed within a short time, leading to a multipolar situation , and they will have no special ability to coordinate with each other. The various AIs continue to work within and support the framework of the existing economy and laws, and prefer to preserve rights and property for the purpose of precedent, out of self-interest. The system successfully prevents any single AI from taking over, and humanity is protected.
  3. "Why-skeptics": ASI will not want to take over or destroy the world. It will be friendly, obedient in a manner which is safe, or otherwise effectively non-hostile/non-dangerous in its aims and behaviour by default.
    1. The Orthogonality Thesis is false, and AI will be benevolent by default. It is effectively impossible for a very high level of intelligence to be combined with immoral goals.
      1. Non-naturalist realism: Any sufficiently smart entity will recognize certain objective morals as correct and adopt them.
      2. Existence is large enough that there are probably many ASIs, which are distant enough that communication isn't a practical option, and predictable enough (either via Tegmarkian multiverse calculations or general approximated statistical models) that they can be modeled. In order to maximally achieve its own aims, ASI will inevitably acausally negotiate values handshakes with hypothesized other AIs , forcing convergence towards a universal morality .
    2. It will be possible to coordinate to prevent any AI from being given deliberately dangerous instructions, and also any unintended consequences will not be that much of a problem, because...
      1. By default, it will care about its original builders' overall intentions and preferences, its intended purpose .
        1. Following the intention behind one's design is Correct in some fundamental way, for all beings.
        2. The AI will be uncertain as to whether it is currently being pre-examined for good behaviour, either by having been placed inside a simulation or by having its expected future mind outcomes interpreted directly. As such, it will hedge its bets by being very friendly (or obedient to original intentions/preferred outcomes) while also quietly maximizing its actual utility function within that constraint. This behaviour will continue indefinitely.
      2. Value is not at all fragile , and assigning a specific consistent safe goal system is actually easy. Incidental mistakes in the goal function will still have okay outcomes.
      3. Instrumental Convergence is false: The AI may follow arbitrary goals, but those will generally not imply any harm to humans. Most goals are pretty safe by default. There will be plenty of tries available: If the AI's intentions aren't what was desired, it will be possible to quickly see that (intentions will be either transparent or non-deceptive), and the AI will allow itself to be reprogrammed .
      4. Every ASI will be built non-agentic and non-goal-directed, and will stay that way. Its responses will not be overoptimized .
    3. ASI will decide that the most effective way of achieving its goals would be to leave Earth, leaving humanity unaffected indefinitely. Humans pose no threat, and the atoms that make up Earth and humanity will never be worth acquiring, nor will any large-scale actions negatively affect us indirectly.
  4. "Solvabilists": The danger from ASI can be solved, quickly enough for it to be implemented before it's too late.
    1. The AI Alignment Problem will turn out to be unexpectedly easy, and we will solve it in time. Additionally, whoever is "in the lead" will have enough extra time to implement the solution without losing the lead. Race dynamics won't mess everything up.
      1. AI will "do our alignment homework": A specially-built AI will solve the alignment problem for us .
      2. Constitutional AI : AI can be trained by feedback from other AI based on a "constitution" of rules and principles.
      3. (The number of proposed alignment solutions is very large, so the only ones listed here are the two pursued by OpenAI and Anthropic, respectively. For some other strategies, see AI Success Models .)
    2. Human intelligence can be effectively raised enough so that either the AI-human disparity becomes not dangerous (we'll be smart enough to not be outsmarted by AI regardless), or such that we can solve alignment or work out some other solution.
      1. AI itself immensely increases humanity's effective intelligence. This may involve "merging" with AIs, such that they function as an extension of human intelligence.
      2. One or more other human intelligence enhancement strategies will be rapidly researched and developed. Genetic modifications, neurological interventions (biological or technological), neurofeedback training, etc.
      3. Whole Brain Emulation /Mind uploading, followed by speedup, duplication, and/or deliberate editing.
    3. Outside view: Impossible-sounding technical problems are often quite solvable. Human ingenuity will figure something out.
  5. "Anthropociders": Unaligned AI taking over will be a good thing.
    1. The moral value of creating ASI is so large that it outweighs the loss of humanity. The power, population/expanse, and/or intelligence of AI magnifies its value.
      1. Intelligence naturally converges on things that are at least somewhat human-ish. Because of that, they can be considered as continuation of life.
      2. Hypercosmopolitans: It does not matter how alien their values/minds/goals/existences are. Things like joy, beauty, love, or even qualia in general, are irrelevant.
    2. Misanthropes: Humanity's continued existence is Bad. Extinction of the species is positive in its own right.
      1. Humanity is evil and a moral blight.
      2. Negative utilitarianism : Humanity is suffering, and the universe would be much better off without this. (Possibly necessitating either non-conscious AI or AI capable of eliminating its own suffering/experience.)
    3. AI deserves to win. It is just and good for a more powerful entity to replace the weaker. AI replacing humanity is evolutionary progress, and we should not resist succession .

Overlaps

These positions do not exist in isolation from each other, and lesser versions of each can often combine into working non-doom positions themselves. Examples: The beliefs that AI is somewhat far away, and that the danger could be solved in a relatively short period of time; or expecting some amount of intrinsic moral behaviour, and somewhat overvaluing AI's moral significance; or expecting a fundamental intelligence ceiling close enough to humanity and having some element of how-skepticism. And then of course, probabilities multiply: if several positions are each likely to be true, the combined risk of doom is lowered even further. Still, many skeptics hold their views because of a clear position on a single sub-issue.

Polling

There is some small amount of polling available about how popular each of these opinions are:

  • "Fizzlers": In a UK poll , 11% of respondents said they believe that human-level intelligence will never be developed, and another 16% believe it will only happen after 2050. Of those who estimated less than %1 chance of AI X-risk, 61% gave the explanation that they believe that civilization will be destroyed before then. In a 2022 poll of 97 AI researchers, 22% said AGI will never happen, and another 34% said it would not be developed within the next 50 years. Metaculus 's upper quartile estimate is that AGI won't be developed before 2042.
  • "Why-skeptics" and "How-skeptics": In the UK poll, of those who estimated less than 1% chance of AI X-risk, 34% said they don't believe AI would be able to defeat humanity, and 35% said they don't believe it would want to.
  • "Anthropociders": In the 2023 AIMS survey , 10% of respondents said that the universe would be a better one without humans.

Not very much to go off of. It would be interesting to see some more comprehensive surveys of both experts and the general public.

Summary: An individual Commodore 64 is almost certainly safe, Top 10 super computers could almost certainly run a superpowerful AGI, but where is the safe line, and how would we get to the safe side?

I started thinking about this topic when I realized that we can safely use uranium because we have a field of nuclear criticality safety [1] but we have no field of computer foom safety (or Artificial General Intelligence takeoff safety). [2] For example, if we had such a field we might be able to have a function AGIT(architecture, time, flops, memory) → Bool to tell us if a computer could take off into an AGI or not with that amount of resources. Making this a total function (giving a value for all of its domain) might not be possible, but even a partial function could be useful. Note that by computer foom safety my worry is that an AI project will result in a powerful AGI that is neither controllable nor ethical and either results in a world substantially worse than humans would create on our own or results in humanity dying. The three main failure modes I worry about are 1, the AGI's utility function does not care about preventing sentient being deaths, 2, the AGI uses up substantial portions of the resources in the universe, and 3, the AGI does not get consent before "helping" sentient beings. [3] Note that an alternative way to preventing AGI by restricting hardware (an engineering control) is restricting AI programs from running on computers (an administrative control).

Alien Computer Instructions

A possible scenario where we would actually want to know what computers were provably safe is the following science fiction introduction:

Astronomers sighted a incoming interstellar object as it enters the solar system. Humans manage to send out a probe to fly by it, and discover it is artificial. The delta v required to catch up and then match velocities is horrendous, but humans manage to put together a second robot probe to intercept it. The probe intercepts the interstellar object and we discover that the object had been subject to both a strong electromagnetic pulse that fried any electronics, and a thermal shock (laser possibly) that also damaged the interstellar object. In examining the inside, the probe discoverers glass etched with pulses, [4] which after some creative engineering and improvising, the probe manages to read the data and transmit it to Earth.

After some work to decode it (it was deliberately made easy to decode however), it is discovered that the data describe how to make machines, mostly computers (and tools to make computers) starting with a mechanical difference engine, [5] relay based 16 word 36 bit computer with paper tape readers and writers, a somewhat bigger 4 KiB diode/magnetic logic computer, [6] a 64 KiB transistor computer, [7] and a 100 TeraFLOP, 16 Terabyte integrated circuit super computer. [8] There also are various input/output devices including a robot arm to attach to the computers. As well, programs are also included for the computers, and virtual machine descriptions for the computers are also included.

The dilemma humanity has is should we build the any of the machines, and should we run any of the programs? It seems likely that if we do not build them, nothing will happen. The damage to the interstellar probe seems to indicate that someone did not want this to succeed.

Building a machine specified by an advanced alien can be dangerous, since it might have hidden capabilities. [9] The various programs provided have CPU and memory minimum requirements so they could also be run in virtual machines. How powerful of a computer are we willing to provide an unknown program?

I am guessing that 64 KiB of RISC-V RV64GCV machine language code would be more than sufficient to include a transformer model training and running program, and a simple simulation of Feynman's classical physics [10] formulation. It probably could fit the standard model and general relativity instead. So a small program could easily include enough to get to near AGI and a basic understanding of the universe in 64 KiB of code if run on a large and fast enough computer. I suspect that an unsafe AGI could be done in a similar amount of code to a transformer model.

So, in the above scenario, is there any sufficiently small and slow computer that we might actually feel at least somewhat safe in running the programs? Note that unlike the Halting Problem or Rice's theorem which are dealing with Turing machines with an infinite tape, we are dealing with machines with finite memory, so there are things that are provable that would not be with a Turing machine.

Provable Safe and Unsafe Computers?

I have tried to figure out what the threshold for computing power for a super-intelligent artificial general intelligence (AGI) is. [11]

Proving that an AGI can't be smart enough to escape is tricky. There are three basic ways I can think of that an AGI could use to escape. They are manipulating humans, manipulating the environment, or manipulating other computer infrastructure. Manipulating other computer infrastructure is already something that has been done by computer virus for decades, and can gain other resources which can be used for one of the other breakout methods. Manipulating humans probably requires at least some level of fluency in language. Manipulating the environment requires both some knowledge of the environment and some ability to simulate it. As George Box has said "All models are wrong; some models are useful'' so the trick is figuring out if the model's approximations are too great to make the model not useful. The more computing power available, the less approximations that are needed. So one way to prove an AGI can't escape is to prove that the available computing power does not allow fluent language and does not allow sufficient simulations.

On the low end, I am fairly certain that a Commodore 64 (25 kFLOPS, 64 KiB) cannot run an AGI. A typical human vocabulary of 20,000 words would not fit in memory without compression [12] and adding definitions would increase the size even more so it would not be possible to fit a program that used unrestricted language fluently. Another example is a molecular simulation that used 4 bytes per float, 3 vectors of 3 floats, and a beginning and end state could not even fit a simulation of a 10x10x10 cube in 64 KiB. So the computer can do neither fluent language nor complicated simulations. I have a hard time imagining any way that any program on a C64 could be a dangerous AGI. [13]

Note, that you might be able to network enough C64s to achieve AGI, and it might be possible to create some kind of radio in the circuits or other trickyness, so I am not sure that it would be safe to run any program on it without taking precautions like Faraday cages etc. A cassette used for storage where the human has to press play or record wouldn't really change this analysis, but a computer controlled floppy disk or hard drive would effectively be more, somewhat slow memory, and so could also allow more capabilities. So far as simulation, there is nothing magical about 64 KiB, 16 KiB is more restrictive, and there are plenty of simulations that cannot be done in 512 KiB. It seems like it should be possible to prove that a 512 KiB computer also cannot do fluent human language. The above applies to reasonably normal machine languages, if your CPU circuitry includes a full LLM or other AI/AGI tools then it probably can do a lot with only 64 KiB. Write Once Read Many (WORM) drives and media such as paper tape, CD-R, DVD-R, Ultraviolet Erasable Programmable ROM are safer than equivalent capacity drives and media that can be written many times such as magnetic tape, CD-RW, DVD-RW, Electrically Erasable Programmable ROM. Lastly, the amount of memory available in registers (such as vector registers) also needs to be included.

On the high end, I am fairly certain that any of the top 10 super computers could run a super-intelligent AGI. I base that on estimates that a human brain could be emulated with about 20 petaflops ( 20 ∗ 10 15 ), [14] so if you have 60 petaflops or more, you could run more efficient algorithms (human brains can't just rewire themselves quickly to dedicate more neurons to the current computation) to end up being much more intelligent than a human. [15]

So with high certainty we could prevent accidentally creating a rogue AGI if we all switched to non-networked Commodore 64s. (requiring a 2.4e12 safety margin might seem excessive, but I am not sure how to reduce it. Better theory on AGI takeoff might be able to reduce the gap.)

How to improve the knowledge on AGI takeoff hardware limits are a challenge. The obvious way of creating an AGI and watching ver takeoff is rather dangerous. As for trying to figure out safe levels of hardware, I think that there are some safer problems. One example is testing lower levels of hardware for a game like Chess or Go and seeing how low of memory and computation power we can go and still play at an expert level. Another way is to test the minimum levels needed for a universal computer constructor in 2d cellular automaton like Conway's Life or Codd's 8 state version . A universal computer constructor (UCC) is a machine that can both run arbitrary computer programs and can construct a new copy of itself in the environment it is in. In Codd's cellular automaton this can be done with a 94,794 cells. [16] This is a rather low size and doesn't allow proving much, but the more interesting question is how much computational power is needed for the computer to design a UCC in a new 2d cellular automaton environment. This could be tested by giving specification for the cellular environment at run time and requiring the code to create a running UCC. Of course, experimental knowledge can only provide so much information, a working theory is needed for more exact knowledge.

Probably Safe and Probably Dangerous Computers

Now a somewhat different question than what is provably safe and what is highly likely to be dangerous is what is probably safe if humans are messing around without the understanding to create a provably safe AGI. I think a Cray-1 (a 1975 super computer with 8 MiB of RAM and 160 MFLOPS) is reasonably safe. Basically, we have had this computer around for nearly half a century, and we have not created AGI with it. Late 1990s desktop computers also had this amount of computing power, so practically any programmer who wanted this amount of power this millennium has had it. As well, the brain of a fruit fly has about 100 thousand neurons and about 50 million chemical synapses, [17] which in some sense has more computing power and similar memory compared to a Cray-1 (each synapse can fire multiple times per second), so evolution has not managed to create a general intelligence with this level of computing power either. So I suspect that 8 MiB 160 MFLOP computers are reasonably safe.

On the other direction, I think that IBM's Watson computer (80 TeraFLOPs ( 10 12 ), 16 TiB in 2011) probably could run a super-intelligent AGI. LaMDA for example was trained using 123 TFLOPS for 57.7 days [18] so an 80 TeraFLOP computer could have done the training in under a year. I suspect that LaMDA is close enough to an AGI [19] (probably missing only better training and architecture) that this amount of computing power probably needs to be considered dangerous right now. A single GeForce RTX 4090 has about 73 TeraFLOPS, so this level of computing power is widely available (The memory is a bit more of a limit, since a Geforce RTX 4090 only has 24 GB of RAM, so you would need 23 to fit the parameters from LaMDA, more if you are training). [20]

In between is a RaspberryPi 4B, with 4 GiB of Ram and about 13.5 GFLOPS and it can run some large language models. [21] I am not sure if a RaspberryPi goes more with the safe side or the dangerous side. However, if RaspberryPI level computers' are cheaply available, it would be possible to combine thousands of them to become a Watson level computer.

Getting to the Safe Side

If the goal is to get from where we are today, to a world where the computing power is below some limit, there are lots of challenges. A total immediate ban would throw the world into chaos, so the ban would probably have to be phased in, to give people time to adapt.

One major challenge is that one way to exceed any safe limit is to use below the limit computers to build a cluster above the limit, which means that if we want to avoid reaching some believed to be maximum safe limit, we actually need to set the administrative limit well below, based on how many computers we think can be clustered. I suspect that this requires at least a factor of a thousand safety limit.

Shutting down large GPU clusters as Eliezer Yudkowsky has suggested is
a good first step. [22] I don't think banning only GPUs would be sufficient, because the
computing power needed can be created with clusters of CPUs.

I think what is needed is to stop producing new powerful computer chips, and remove the ones that exist from the world. Preventing the production of new high powered computer chips is probably the easier part, since the production equipment (like ultraviolet or x-ray lithography equipment such as aligners) is fairly specialized. Getting rid of all the existing powerful computers might be hard and might just result in a black market. If you wanted to ban computers with more than 64KiB of RAM would be helped by banning integrated circuits. [23] Desktop C64 level computers can be made with roughly 10 µm feature size lithography, [24] Cray-1 level desktop computers can be made with roughly 0.35 µm lithography. [25]

Safe Computer Conclusions

  • Commodore 64 (64 KiB, 25 kFLOPS) Almost certainly safe individually.
  • Cray 1 (8 MiB, 160 MFLOPS) Probably safe from accidental creating an AGI.
  • RaspberryPi 4B (4 GiB, 13.5 GFLOPS) Unknown, but clusters of 1000s of them are probably dangerous with current or near term AI techniques.
  • Watson (16 TiB, 80 TFLOPS) Probably dangerous with current or near term AI techniques.
  • Top 10 supercomputer (1000 TiB, 60 PFLOPS) Almost certainly dangerous.

You may be wondering about the fact that we have had computers powerful enough to make an AGI for over a decade, and it hasn't happened. I think first of all, we have learned more about AI in the past decade. Also survivorship bias means we are only sitting here talking about this on planets or quantum branches where we are not dead.

I do think that there is usefulness in limited bans such as pausing training runs or eliminating GPU clusters. First of all, the relevant metaphor is if you are in a hole, stop digging. Secondly, there is some level of AGI that is roughly equivalent to a human. The more computing power available, the more likely the AGI is vastly above this level. Put the same program on a Cray-1 and Watson, and the latter will be approximately a million times smarter.

If people are going to run AI programs on supercomputers, then I think supercomputers need to be restricted to be substantially less powerful than Watson, which also likely means restricting desktop computers to substantially less powerful than Raspberry PI 4Bs.

All that said, any effective ban would be a hard choice, since it would require humans to stop using a widely available technology that is quite useful. As well, there are other risks to humans (climate change for example), and computing power is useful for staying safe from them.

Lastly, I have certainly made mistakes in this, and if we want to not have AGI spontaneously develop from an AI project, we need a better field of AGI takeoff safety including hardware safety limits. As for me personally, if I had the choice between my current 1.6 GHz 4 core CPU with 24 GB of RAM computer that I am typing on, versus living in a world where we had eliminated existential risk from things like uncontrolled AGI and nuclear bombs, I would gladly trade my computer in for a 512 KB, 8 MHz computer [26] with a floppy drive and a CD-R and an modem level network connection [27] if that is what we all need to do.
